See www.38north.org
excellent summary
"North Korean offensive cyber operations have been conducted to collect sensitive political and military intelligence information, to lash out at enemies who threaten their beliefs and interests, and most interestingly, to generate revenue. This revenue generation aspect of North Korean operations was thrust into the international spotlight when, in early 2016, unauthorized transfers of funds from the Bangladesh Central Bank were issued using the Society for Worldwide Interbank Financial Telecommunication (SWIFT) network for global banking. The attempted transfers amounting to over $950 million USD sought to move funds to entities in locations such as Sri Lanka and the Philippines; ultimately $81 million USD in funds disappeared into the ether. The subsequent investigation revealed that the perpetrators of the attack used tools to securely delete records from the SWIFT terminals that would alert Bangladesh Central Bank employees of the transfers. Commonly referred to as a “wiper,” this secure deletion tool contained code that was linked by many in the computer security industry to one used in attacks associated with North Korea, notably the attack on SPE through a US Computer Emergency Response Team (USCERT) alert. The revelation that a state would engage in such a flagrant violation of international norms came as a surprise to many in the information security arena. North Korea watchers were, of course, not surprised as the currency generation activities benefiting the Kim family and their isolated nation have been well understood for some time.

DPRK has been active in developing their cyber capabilities and will further develop this capability to mitigate the conventional advantages US forces possess.  Low level attacks are most probable as the DPRK test their capabilities.  This forecast is difficult to confirm or deny either way due to difficulties in attribution and the norm for cyber victims to stay quiet about being attacked.

US holiday season starts in December hence upto 30Nov is the most unlikely period.
To strike during festive period raises the chaos multi-fold.

Cyberattacks are difficult to attribute and hard to interpret. NK must clearly signal their strength to perceived aggression. Cyber would muddy the situation and create the possibility of uncontrolled escalation. They'll stick to physical displays of power.
NK will continue to flex conventional muscles rather than cyber in that time period. Perhaps radar locks on aircraft to test reactions rather than cyber.
DPRK has a history of targeted cyber attacks and both critical and non critical cyber infrastructure. They have recently been found to be stealing bitcoin throughout the cyber domain.

There are three holidays in DPRK during this window.  Although the focus currently is on crypto-currency, Party Foundation Day on 10 October is the perfect opportunity to turn that focus toward the US, specifically on one of the three 1. Media (Twitter, News outlets, Etc); 2. Defense (any DOD target); or 3.  The White house.

I do not think that North Korea will now try to conduct a cyber attack against the US, because now it is trying to prove that by conducting her missiles tests and nuclear tests it does not harm the sovereignty of any country, but of course, she want to show up that if she is attacked, she has the power to defend herself. In addition, it is very difficult to determine, in case of a cyber attack, who is the true aggressor. In that sense, I believe that if the conflict continues to escalate, in the future yes, it is possible that this type of action will be initiated by North Korea, but not yet.

I estimate that there is a 45% likelihood of a North Korean cyber attack on a US entity in the next two months based on review of past forecasts and research on 2016 report cyber attacks. The estimate takes into account that the attacks may include low level attacks such as denial services. In 2016 there were two reported cyber attacks that fit this description originating in North Korea.  The rising tensions between the two nations also plays a role in the likelihood of cyber attacks. In conclusion the recent activity of the nations leaders, past activity of North Korean cyber, and other forecasters I estimate that there is a 45% chance of a cyber attack on any US entity by North Korea.

Distribution of responses (not weighted yet with scores) and quick look at 2016 cyber incidents tips this forecast over the 50% mark.  Rising tensions could make a cyber incident a "cheap signal" of resolve (certainly cheaper than detonating a hydrogen bomb over the Pacific).  Furthermore, DPRK DOES possess the capability to conduct cyber attacks (esp. low-level) and demonstrate intent.  See: https://jsis.washington.edu/news/north-korea-cyber-attacks-new-asymmetrical-military-strategy/

A low-cost way for North Korea to resist. Also economic sanctions would justify money theft such as Bangladesh Central Reserve robbery and attacks on US banking system. Also seems to show some interest in utility power disruption. A question is whether there will be attribution to North Korea or not. Trump family businesses would be an interesting target given personal animosity Trump has created with North Korea.  Timing  would increase around late October harvest which maybe disappointing.

The prior DPRK cyber attacks appear to have the intention of causing chaos, therefore displaying the power to cause chaos.  Their missile systems are working great, but Japan and the world are growing weary.  Their nuclear weapons are detonating as planned.  Cyber attacks are inexpensive and the DPRK can maintain their threatening stance by using non-conventional warfare displays.  Switching to cyber warfare to hold serve for a bit longer makes sense for the DPRK.  Firing missiles over Japan and more nuclear tests seems unsustainable without causing a conventional war and destruction of the regime.
